questions.chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics
questions.explanation: When H₀ is actually false and you correctly reject it, this is a correct decision known as statistical power (1 - β). This is often confused with simply a 'Correct Decision' (which occurs when H₀ is true and you fail to reject it) or with Type I/Type II errors, but power specifically refers to the probability of correctly detecting a real effect by rejecting a false null hypothesis.

The key limitation of concurrent validity is that because the criterion is measured at the same time as the predictor (using current group members rather than applicants), the results may not generalize to predictive situations where the goal is to forecast future performance. This contrasts with the limitation of predictive validity, which is that it is time-consuming and subject to attrition.

questions.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
questions.explanation: The SAT/GRE subtest standard score transformation has a mean of 500 and a standard deviation of 100. This is reflected in the formula Score = 100z + 500, where 100 is the SD multiplied by the z-score. Common confusions include the SD of 15 (IQ scores), 10 (T-scores), or 2 (stanines).

questions.chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics
questions.explanation: According to Cohen's conventions for interpreting effect size using Cohen's d, a value of 0.5 represents a medium effect. This is distinct from 0.2 (small effect) and 0.8 (large effect). These three benchmarks (0.2, 0.5, 0.8) are commonly tested on the EPPP and are easily confused with one another.

Negative Reinforcement involves removing (-) an aversive stimulus to increase behavior. 'Negative' refers to the removal of a stimulus, and 'reinforcement' refers to the increase in behavior. This is commonly confused with Negative Punishment, which also involves removing a stimulus but decreases behavior instead.

According to Cohen's conventions for interpreting correlation coefficients, an absolute value of r ranging from .30 to .49 represents a medium (moderate) correlation. This is distinct from .10 to .29 (small/weak) and .50 and above (large/strong).

rows: Best when missing a case is costly
Best when false alarms are costly
questions.explanation: A higher cutoff score means fewer people are identified as positive, which increases specificity (correctly identifying true negatives) while decreasing sensitivity. This is the complementary trade-off to a lower cutoff, which increases sensitivity at the expense of specificity.

When the test result is negative but the condition is actually present, this represents a False Negative (FN) — the test incorrectly classified someone who has the condition as not having it. This is distinct from a True Negative, which occurs when the test is negative and the condition is truly absent.

rows: Every member has equal chance of selection
Population divided into strata; random sampling within each
Randomly select clusters (e.g., schools), sample all within
Select every kth member from a list
questions.explanation: Stratified random sampling divides the population into meaningful strata (subgroups) before randomly sampling within each stratum. Its key advantage is that it ensures adequate representation of specific subgroups, which distinguishes it from simple random sampling (which provides unbiased but not guaranteed subgroup representation) and cluster sampling (which is valued for geographic practicality).

A Cronbach's alpha in the .70 - .79 range is generally considered 'Acceptable' and is often regarded as the minimum threshold for research purposes. This is commonly confused with 'Good' (.80-.89) or 'Questionable' (.60-.69), but .70 is the widely cited minimum acceptable standard for research reliability.

questions.chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics
questions.explanation: The Kruskal-Wallis H test is the non-parametric alternative to the one-way ANOVA, used when comparing three or more independent groups and the assumptions of parametric tests (e.g., normality, homogeneity of variance) are not met. The Friedman Test is its counterpart for related samples, while the Mann-Whitney U and Wilcoxon Signed-Rank are used for two-group comparisons.

rows: All items assumed equally discriminating; no guessing. Simplest model; emphasizes measurement properties and specific objectivity
Allows items to vary in discrimination. ICCs can differ in steepness. More realistic for many tests
questions.correct_value: Accounts for correct guessing on multiple-choice items. Lower asymptote of ICC is above zero. Most commonly used for standardized multiple-choice tests
options: All items assumed equally discriminating; no guessing. Simplest model; emphasizes measurement properties and specific objectivity
Allows items to vary in discrimination. ICCs can differ in steepness. More realistic for many tests
Accounts for correct guessing on multiple-choice items. Lower asymptote of ICC is above zero. Most commonly used for standardized multiple-choice tests
Accounts for item response time and difficulty. Lower asymptote of ICC is at zero. Most commonly used for adaptive testing
questions.explanation: The 3PL model adds a guessing parameter (c) to difficulty and discrimination, which raises the lower asymptote of the item characteristic curve (ICC) above zero. This reflects the reality that on multiple-choice items, examinees can sometimes answer correctly by guessing, even when their ability is very low. This makes the 3PL the most commonly used model for standardized multiple-choice tests.
